title: Multisig & Security
introText: Test your knowledge on signatures, thresholds, and secure storage.

q1.question: Why is multisig used?
q1.a1: To reduce the risk of individual key losses.
q1.a1fb: Correct: Multiple signatures reduce individual risk.
q1.a2fb: Incorrect: Multisig increases security, not fees.
q1.a3fb: False: Multisig is not designed for speed.

q2.question: When is a transaction on a multisig account valid?
q2.a1: If the signatures reach the required threshold.
q2.a1fb: Correct: The sum of the weights must meet the threshold.
q2.a2: As soon as any signature is present.
q2.a2fb: Incorrect: A single signature is not sufficient if the threshold is higher.
q2.a3: Only with the master key, regardless of the threshold.
q2.a3fb: Incorrect: The master key is also subject to thresholds.

q3.question: What happens when thresholds are set incorrectly?
q3.hint: Values that are too high or too low have consequences.
q3.a1: Transactions could be blocked or released too easily.
q3.a1fb: Correct: Incorrect thresholds lead to lockouts or insufficient security.
q3.a2: Not at all, thresholds are just information.
q3.a2fb: Incorrect: Thresholds control how many signatures are necessary.
q3.a3: The account sequence number is being reset.
q3.a3fb: Incorrect: Thresholds have no impact on the sequence.

q4.question: How many signatures does a transaction require with Threshold med?
q4.a1: Weights of the signatures must at least reach the med-threshold.
q4.a1fb: Correct: The median threshold applies to payments.
q4.a2fb: Incorrect: It depends on weights and thresholds.
q4.a3fb: Incorrect: Only enough signatures to meet the threshold.

q5.question: How should secret keys be stored in real multisig setups?
q5.a1fb: Correct: Signatures should be collected separately.
q5.a2: All on the same laptop for convenience.
q5.a2fb: Incorrect: A device poses a single point of failure.
q5.a3: Share in plain text in a chat.
